title: 107_hr744
content: The "Medical Research Investment Act of 2001" increases the limitation on charitable deduction for contributions for medical research. The "Medical Research Investment Act of 2001" amends the percentage limitations for charitable deductions related to medical research contributions in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It introduces a special limitation where medical research contributions are allowed up to 80 percent of the taxpayer's contribution base for any taxable year. The taxable year allows charitable contributions exceeding the limitation to be carried over for 10 years as medical research contributions. "In the case of any medical research contribution of capital gain property, subsection (e)(1) applies. A 'medical research contribution' is a charitable contribution to an organization for conducting medical research." The term 'medical research' is defined as per regulations under subparagraph (A)(ii). Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code regarding medical research contributions. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code allow for deductions on medical research contributions made after December 31, 2001. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code allow for deductions on medical research contributions made after December 31, 2001, with section 170(b)(1)(G) applied to contributions made after December 31, 1999. SEC. 3. Treatment of certain incentive stock options. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include nonrecognition of certain incentive stock options, with an exception for medical research stock transfers in the same taxable year as the exercise. The amendment adds a new paragraph stating that medical research stock transfers will be treated as meeting certain requirements. The effective date for these amendments applies to transfers of stock made after the date of the enactment of the Act.
